name: netstat
desc: Netstat is a command-line tool used to display the network connections (both incoming and outgoing), routing tables, and network interface statistics.

-a.name: Display all connections and listening ports.

-b.name: Display the executable involved in creating each connection or listening port.

-c.name: Display the TCP/IP statistics for every established connection.

-e.name: Display the Ethernet statistics. This may be combined with the -s option.

-f.name: Display the FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name) for foreign addresses.

-n.name: Displays addresses and port numbers in numerical form.

-o.name: Display the owning process ID associated with each connection.

-p.name: Displays the protocol (TCP, UDP, TCPv6, or UDPv6).

-s.name: Display per-protocol statistics. By default, statistics are shown for the TCP, UDP, ICMP, and IP protocols. This may be combined with the -p option.

-t.name: Display the current status of TCP connections.

-u.name: Display the current status of UDP connections.

-w.name: Display raw data from the network in a format suitable for analysis.

-x.name: Display NetworkDirect connections, applicable only to Windows Server.

content:
Example

  • Show all connections and listening ports: netstat -a
  • Show TCP connections: netstat -t
  • Show UDP connections: netstat -u
  • Show the executable file that is associated with each connection: netstat -b
  • Show full domain name: netstat -f
  • Show addresses and port numbers in numerical form: netstat -n
  • Show the process ID that owns each connection: netstat -o
  • Show routing table: netstat -r
  • Show active tasks: netstat -v
  • Show network statistics: netstat -c
  • Show raw data on all connections and listening ports: netstat -w
  • Show connections that are associated with a specified protocol: netstat -p protocol_name
  • Show statistics for each protocol: netstat -s protocol_name
  • Show Ethernet statistics: netstat -e
  • Show NetworkDirect connections: netstat -x
